Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Understanding and Reducing Student Resistance as a Barrier to Faculty Change

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This WIDER research project focuses on understanding student resistance as a barrier to STEM faculty adoption of evidence-based teaching methods in the context of introductory engineering courses at University of Michigan, Virginia Tech, North Carolina A & T, and Bucknell University. The project is investigating three related research questions, including: 1) What factors (including faculty strategies, student experience, institution and course type, and student and faculty characteristics) influence student resistance to nontraditional teaching methods? 2) To what extent does expectancy violation theory explain student resistance to nontraditional teaching methods? and 3) What specific, evidence-based strategies (and in what contexts) can faculty employ to significantly reduce student resistance? To address these questions, the project team is employing rigorous instrument development procedures to design surveys to measure student resistance and expectancy violation, and conducting in-depth studies at a range of institutions, combining qualitative methods with quantitative surveys to identify additional factors related to student resistance. The final phase of the project includes a full-scale study of 20 introductory engineering courses. Expected products include evidence-based strategies faculty can use to reduce student resistance, student surveys that faculty can use to monitor their own progress in reducing student resistance, and a classroom observation protocol focusing on student resistance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There have been calls to improve engineering education instruction in undergraduate classrooms across the nation. Research has shown that improved teaching methods such as active learning help with engineering and science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) students' retention, learning gains, engagement, motivation, and satisfaction. However, many undergraduate engineering classrooms remain traditional and lecture-based. Previous research has shown that some engineering instructors are reluctant to incorporate new teaching methods in their classrooms because they anticipate students will not like and may resist such teaching methods. This research project explored how and if students resisted nontraditional teaching methods such as active learning. The research project also explored strategies for instructors to reduce student resistance.

 

We created the Student Response to Instructional Practices (StRIP) survey to carefully examine how students responded and resisted different teaching methods in their classrooms. The survey was constructed to be reliable and valid with multiple rounds of survey testing, pilot classrooms, focus groups, and observations. The final survey was administered to students and instructors in 18 different undergraduate engineering classrooms throughout the United States. Approximately 1000 students participated in the survey.

 

We found that many of the students responded positively to active learning in their classrooms. Engineering instructors should find relief in knowing that the many students do enjoy active learning and nontraditional teaching methods in their classrooms. Cases of student resistance were minimal, and when we interviewed instructors about student resistance, most instructors were only able to give a few examples of when students resisted. Many students on average did not appear to resist active learning.

 

We proceeded to understand what predicted a students? response to active learning. We found that students' responses to active learning were greatly explained by the perceived usage of instructor strategies more than other factors. It seemed that students responded well to how instructors implemented active learning in the classrooms.  Instructors should be mindful of two types of instructor strategies: explanation and facilitation. Explanation strategies make expectations for the in-class activity or the nontraditional teaching method clear. Facilitation strategies occur after the in-class activity has started, and facilitation strategies guide and help students throughout the in-class activity. A list of empirically validated instructor strategies is below:

Explanation strategies

  • Clearly explain the purpose of the activities.
  • Discuss how the activities relate to students' learning.
  • Clearly explain what students are expected to do for the activities.

Facilitation strategies

  • Encourage students to engage with the activities through his/her demeanor.
  • Invite students to ask questions about the activities.
  • Walk around the room to assist students with the activities, if needed.
  • Solicit student feedback about the activities.

 

In sum, contrary to the fears of many engineering instructors, student resistance to nontraditional teaching methods and active learning is not widespread. This finding should help more instructors adopt proven research-based instructional strategies and teaching methods in their classrooms. We have also explored and verified practical and useful instructor strategies to consider when implementing nontraditional teaching methods and active learning in the classroom. Instructors should benefit knowing that these strategies can help ease them into using proven research based teaching methods. The nation will benefit from having more STEM and engineering students succeed in their classrooms.
